page.title: 03HITCHIN MARKET (2)
page.content: In 1268 the market was established at Bancroft, a wide street suitable for a market. In the 19th century this proved a cause of annoyance. Local farmers and dealers complained about the lack of accomodation for the livestock, the number of cattle increased but the pens decreased. The reason was the opening of a new road,to the station,Hermitage Road.By 1857 a request was made for a plot of land between West Lane and Old Park Road. It was then proposed to move the cattle to an 'out of town' site, but this was eventually rejected in 1883 because of the cost. In 1903 new rules forced the market at Bancroft to close. A new cattle market established at Nun's Close,this land was leased for 99 years from Trinity College, Cambridge.Today it is run as an auction for produce and small animals.
